section.name: Internationalization
section.p: Attention! This is concerning the general magnolia i18n mechanism. To make your content (paragraphs) multi-language capable you should read this first.

subsection.name: Configuration
subsection.p: the configuration is done in Config repository: /server/i18n:

UL.LI: define the application language (change the language node)
the fall back language is en

ul.li: Each module has his own messages bundle

subsection.name: JSP
subsection.P: Use the standard fmt JSTL Tags

subsection.name: Java (servlet, beans, ..)
subsection.P: Use the MessagesManager.getMessages(request, ...) to get the Messages or MessagesManager.get(request, ....) to get a string. The mechanism will handle the exception if the request is null.

subsection.name: javax.servlet.jsp.jstl.fmt.LocaleSupport
subsection.P: If you can provide a PageContext, you can use the static methods of this class. Our system is behaving like JSTL so you will get the same result.

subsection.name: Dialogs, Paragraphs
subsection.P:
the labels, .. can define a key which is searched in this order
info.magnolia.module.admininterface.messages_templating_custom.properties
info.magnolia.module.admininterface.messages_templating.properties
if not found return the label (it is not a key)
The class used in this case is TemplateMessagesUtil providing some static methods.

subsection.name: messages_templating and messages_templating_custom
subsection.P: I separated the strings, because we said that a bundle must be translated fully. in the messages_templating are our delilvered dialog, paragraph strings. If someone needs his own i18n-dialogs he will put the strings in messages_templating_custom. In this way he can have chinese-dialogs without a fully translated chinese-magnolia.

subsection.name: Javascript
subsection.P: Use the Object mgnlMessages.get(key, basename, args[]) . basename and args are optional.
subsection.p: Keys starting with js. will be added to the mgnlMessages-Object by admintemplate/js/messages.jsp

subsection.name: UTF-8 in java properties files
subsection.p:
Java properyfiles are encoded in iso-8859-1. this standard does not support special characters. but there is an escaping mechanism to use unicode characters (utf-8) in this propertyfiles.
An excample of a french propertyfile: menu.roles=R\u00f4le To make a proper file you can save your native textfile with utf-8 and then transform it into this special java-format. You can use therfore the java tool native2ascii.
native2ascii -encoding UTF-8 messages_fr.txt messages_fr.properties
To get a utf-8 file out of a propertyfile you will use:
native2ascii -reverse -encoding UTF-8 messages_fr.properties messages_fr.txt
